Hi, Steve.

I am planning to run the experiment without some of the outputs=
, that 
are not nessecary for walking, as Ken suggested. 

But you are damn=
 right! As I read your thoughts, some things came to 
my mind:

1. Feedback=
 can be achieved as adding more inputs that represent the 
ACTUAL joint ang=
les at the moment.

2. Additional inputs can be added that are dependant on=
 the collision 
detection procedure, I mean something like "sense of touch"=
. 

3. It is possible to measure the energy exhausted for the muscle 
movem=
ents, so that can be taken into account in the fitness function. 

4. The s=
calability of the substrate space (node density) is just one 
of the featur=
es of HyperNEAT. It is not nessesarry to use that. The 
idea here is to use=
 the geometry of the body. A 100 neurons 
controlling the arm will not help=
 much. Just 3 are enough :) 

I will keep on working on this. It is interes=
ting and my primary goal 
is to achieve the same complexity and realism as =
the models used in 
NaturalMotion. I am planning to use that for computer g=
ames 
(something that is already a fact - see Euphoria). But open source. I=
 
hate this commercial shit out there.

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com,=
 Stephen Waits <steve@...> wrote:
>
> Stephen Waits wrote:
> > 
> > Good ne=
ws.. it seems to run on my machine at work.
> 
> After having run it for al=
most four hours.. a few random thoughts.  
I'm 
> sure you've thought about=
 these things much more than me, 
especially 
> since these aren't much mor=
e than 2 second impulses through my tiny 
brain :)
> 
> * As Ken says, obje=
ctive function is going to be important, but I 
think 
> it may not be the =
*most* important step toward success.
> 
> * I wondered about the ability o=
f your body configuration to 
actually 
> stand up?  In that sense, are seg=
ment masses appropriate?  Joint 
limits? 
>   Joint accelerations?  Can the=
 muscular forces react quickly and 
> forcefully enough?  For example, I ca=
n recover from leaning/falling 
> forward with a single leg (i.e. a "lunge"=
).  I can furthermore 
support 
> my entire body weight with a single leg.
=
> 
> * I believe we humans have an AWFUL LOT of feedback.  Is it ten 
times=
 as 
> much feedback as it actually is muscle command paths?  Something 
li=
ke 
> that.  Anyway, seems that this task is very heavily dependent on 
lot=
s of 
> good feedback.  As an example, I'm seeing quite a bit of this: a) 
=
find a 
> position that is nearly balanced, b) hold it, c) fall over.  What=
's 
your 
> feedback look like right now?
> 
> * I'm also seeing quite a bi=
t of the weird "squatting toe-stand" 
> position, for lack of a better desc=
ription.  This brings to mind 
the 
> idea of pain.  It hurts me to stand o=
n my toes.  More feedback.
> 
> * The problem of balance is incredibly comp=
lex (like I need to 
mention 
> this, right?).  There's a certain level of =
granularity that are 
probably 
> beyond simulation.  For example, we use o=
ur toes quite a bit when 
> standing ourselves upright.  In some ways, this=
 extra complexity 
may be 
> necessary to efficiently stand; however, in bi=
gger ways (as Ken 
eludes 
> to), they only complicate the search space.
> =

> * One fitness related idea I had was to reward individuals that use 
les=
s 
> energy.  For example, to balance, I'd move my arms first, because 
it'=
s 
> easier, than moving my legs.
> 
> * I'd like to see you really use the=
 "Hyper" part of "HyperNEAT".  
That 
> is, evolve something simple, than i=
ncrease the substrate density 
with 
> 100's or even 1000's of nodes.
> 
> =
Overall, it's a very cool project.  I'm looking forward to your 
next 
> up=
load and please keep up the great work!!!
> 
> --Steve
>
